physical_object.name: wireless game controller with grey digital camouflage pattern

assignments.utilization_method: Rest the controller upside-down so the two rounded hand-grips point upward. Strike the centre of one up-facing grip with the phone-clamp “hammer head.” The curved hard-plastic shell offers firm initial resistance. As force builds, static friction is suddenly overcome and the controller tips over with an audible plastic clack, creating an abrupt loss of resistance that mimics the rind giving way.

physical_object.name: matte black stainless steel water bottle with Tesla logo

assignments.utilization_method: Stand the full metal bottle upright on the floor or tabletop directly in front of you. Chop downward onto the flat metal cap. The rigid stainless steel yields a loud, sharp impact; continued force causes the smooth cylinder to topple and clang against the surface, creating an immediate loss of resistance that convincingly echoes the crack-and-split moment.

Grip the narrow top knob (about 1.5–2 cm diameter) as the handle and let the heavier main cylinder hang below and forward. The dense 50 g mass gives clear inertia, closely imitating the sensation of a filled mug hanging from a small rod handle.

physical_object.name: green plush turtle shell with white rim

assignments.utilization_method: Grip the plush shell by squeezing a section of the white rim so the large padded mass hangs outward. The soft, substantial volume provides pronounced inertia that lags at swing start and follows through heavily, giving a cushioned but convincing sensation of a weighted axe head.

physical_object.name: black and silver telescoping selfie stick with phone clamp

assignments.utilization_method: Keep the pole retracted and grip the rubber handle; the metal phone clamp on the opposite end delivers pronounced forward weight. This configuration closely mimics an actual hammer: cylindrical grip, clear head-heavy balance, and sufficient length for wrist-plus-elbow swings.

Hold the inner cardboard core at one edge with a firm grip, allowing the bulk of the roll to extend forward. The cylindrical handle is firm while the paper layers add moderate weight, creating front-loaded inertia. As you swing, sheets flutter and create air resistance, approximating the drag the sickle experiences before breaking through a stem.
